NewsLine.NewsLineText: SPORT-SOCCER-CHAMPIONS-GROUPS = 2:Soccer-Champions League matches in groups G and H, Sept 24

body.p: LONDON, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Bayern Munich aim to make amends for last week's home defeat by Deportivo Coruna when they travel to French club RC Lens for the second group G match of their Champions League campaign.
Deportivo host five-times European champions AC Milan, who secured a 2-1 win over Lens at San Siro last time out.
Following are brief previews with probable teams of Tuesday's matches (kickoff 1845 GMT):
Group G
RC LENS v BAYERN MUNICH
Last week's defeat at AC Milan could well be followed by another when Lens host 2001 winners Bayern Munich.

The French side will be without defender Adama Coulibaly, who is nursing a painful calf and missed last weekend's 1-0 defeat at Girondins Bordeaux. Lens have suffered three consecutive defeats over the last 10 days and another one against the Germans would be a major blow to their qualifying hopes.
"I hope the wheel of fortune will turn in our favour," said midfielder Seydou Keita. "We must win on Tuesday. We don't have any other options."
Lens: 1-Guillaum Warmuz; 24-Rod Fanni, 6-Jacek Bak, 3-Rigobert Song, 26-Cyril Rool; 5-Jocelyn Blanchard, 11-Stephane Pedron, 7-Antoine Sibierski, 8-Seydou Keita; 28-Dagui Bakari, 21-John Utaka.
Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfeld will be expecting his team to bounce back after going down 3-2 to Deportivo -- their first Champions League defeat at home for five years.

Hitzfeld is sweating over the fitness of Peru striker Claudio Pizarro, a doubtful starter due to a knee injury. "We have very little time left," the coach said after Pizarro had to miss training again on Sunday. "We will decide in Lens whether he plays or not."
The injury prevented Pizarro from playing in Saturday's 3-1 win over Energie Cottbus that sent Bayern's four points clear at the top of the Bundesliga standings.
Hitzfeld will be without defender Bixente Lizarazu, midfielders Sebastian Deisler and Mehmet Scholl and striker Roque Santa Cruz -- all through long-term injuries.
Bayern: 1-Oliver Kahn; 2-Willy Sagnol, 5-Robert Kovac, 25-Thomas Linke, 18-Michael Tarnat; 20-Hasan Salihamidzic, 16-Jens Jeremies, 13-Michael Ballack, 11-Ze Roberto; 9-Elber, 21-Alexander Zickler.
Referee: Lucilio Cardoso Cortez Batista (Portugal)
DEPORTIVO CORUNA v AC MILAN
Deportivo made an impressive start by beating Bayern but now face the remainder of the first group phase without influential playmaker Juan Carlos Valeron.
The Spanish international, who was the architect of their win at the Olympic stadium, faces a two-month lay-off after sustaining a fractured fibula in last weekend's 2-0 league win over Valladolid.

Coach Javier Irureta can either choose to field last season's leading striker Diego Tristan alongside the in-form Roy Makaay up front or adopt a more defensive line-up by bringing in new signing Roberto Acuna.

With Jose Molina still nursing a knee injury, former Real Zaragoza keeper Juanmi looks set to continue between the posts, while defender Donato should keep his place following his assured performances against Bayern and Valladolid.
Deportivo: 25-Juanmi; 12-Lionel Scaloni, 4-Noureddine Naybet, 20-Donato, 3-Enrique Romero; 18-Victor, 6-Mauro Silva, 16-Sergio, 10-Fran; 9-Diego Tristan, 7-Roy Makaay.
AC Milan forward Rivaldo is ready to face his old club after missing his new team's weekend win over Perugia. Rivaldo played for Deportivo for the 1996-7 season before moving on to Barcelona.
Milan coach Carlo Ancelotti is expected to rotate his midfielders, using Clarence Seedorf and Gennaro Gattuso from the start in place of Massimo Ambrosini and Serginho.

AC Milan: 12-Nelson Dida; 14-Dario Simic, 3-Paolo Maldini, 13-Alessandro Nesta, 4-Kakhaber Kaladze; 8-Gennaro Gattuso, 21-Andrea Pirlo, 20-Clarence Seedorf; 10-Rui Costa; 11-Rivaldo, 9-Filippo Inzaghi.
Referee: Kim Milton Nielsen (Denmark)
Group H
CLUB BRUGES v LOKOMTIV MOSCOW
Bruges, who put up a fight in last week's 3-2 defeat by Barcelona, limbered up for their second Champions League outing with a 1-0 victory over Ghent in the Belgian league on Saturday.
The game is an important one as Lokomotiv will probably be the Belgians' main rivals in the race to finish third in the group and thereby qualify for the UEFA Cup third round.
"We're playing at home game so we should have more control over the game," said striker Rune Lange, who scored the winning goal against Ghent.

Bruges: 1-Dany Verlinden; 2-Olivier De Cock, 26-Birger Maertens, 30-Marek Spilar, 5-Peter Van Der Heyden; 16-Serhiy Serebrennikov, 3-Timmy Simons, 8-Gaetan Englebert, 11-Sandy Martens; 18-Andres Mendoza, 7-Gert Verheyen.
Lokomotiv, who had Saturday's Russian premier league match against Alania Vladikavkaz postponed until next month, have plenty of injury worries.

In addition to Russia midfielder Marat Izmailov and Nigerian striker James Obiorah, who have been sidelined for the last two months, Yuri Symin's team have now lost defender Oleg Pashinin after he suffered a leg injury in last week's 2-0 defeat to Galatasaray. He should be replaced by Dmitry Sennikov.

Despite the setbacks, the Russian league leaders are optimistic ahead of their trip to Belgium. "If we can produce even a slight improvement on our performance against Galatasaray, we can do well against Bruges," a Lokomotiv spokesman said. "We may not have done as well as we had hoped, but we can still achieve our goal of qualifying from our group."

Lokomotiv: 1-Sergei Ovchinnikov; 16-Vadim Yevseyev, 2-Gennady Nizhegorodov, 5-Sergei Ignashevich, 17-Dmitry Sennikov; 4-Jacob Lekgetho, 3-Yuri Drozdov, 8-Vladimir Maminov, 10-Dmitry Loskov; 15-Maxim Buznikin, 25-Ruslan Pimenov.
Referee: Paulo Manuel Gomes Costa (Portugal)
GALATASARAY v BARCELONA
Midfielders Berkant Goktan and Mehmet Polat missed training on Saturday through injury and Ayhan Akman may also be sidelined after taking a knock in last week's win over Lokomotiv.
Otherwise, the Galatasaray squad are fit and well-rested after being given the weekend off from domestic league matches.
Coach Fatih Terim is expected to play Christian, the Brazilian striker signed on loan from French club Girondins Bordeaux this season.
Galatasaray: 1-Ali Mondragon, 3-Bulent Korkmaz, 57-Hakan Unsal, 21-Sergio Almaguer, 22-Umit Davala, 4-Joao Batista, 67-Ergun Pembe, 10-Felipe, 11-Hasan Sas, 6-Arif Erdem, 25-Christian.
Though not yet firing on all cylinders Barcelona continued their unbeaten start to the Spanish season with a 2-0 win over city rivals Espanyol on Saturday.

Luis Enrique, who scored in their 1-0 win over Galatasaray at the Ali Sami Yen in last season's second phase match, found the net for the fifth time in four matches against Espanyol and will team up with Dutch striker Patrick Kluivert and Javier Saviola in the Barca frontline.

Argentine midfielder Juan Roman Riquelme is out with a minor groin strain but defender Frank de Boer hopes to shake off a minor muscle strain. Fellow Dutchman Michael Reiziger or Gabri would step in to deputise. Otherwise, coach Louis van Gaal should stick by the side who beat Bruges 3-2 last week.
Barcelona: 26-Victor Valdes; 5-Carles Puyol, 3-Frank de Boer, 35-Fernando Navarro; 17-Gaizka Mendieta, 6-Xavi, 8-Philip Cocu, 31-Thiago Motta; 7-Javier Saviola, 21-Luis Enrique, 9-Patrick Kluivert
Referee: Domenico Messina (Italy)
